questions.text: A 55-year-old postmenopausal woman came with complaints of irregular postmenopausal bleeding, breast tenderness, and abdominal pain. Abdominopelvic ultrasound revealed an adnexal mass. A biopsy from the mass revealed the following picture. Which of the following statement is false regarding the diagnosis?

choices.text: Inhibin B is used as its tumor marker
Coffee bean nuclei are seen on microscopy

questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario along with the biopsy findings is suggestive of the diagnosis as granulosa cell tumor. Activating mutations of the KIT gene are seen in patients with dysgerminoma and not seen in granulosa cell tumors.

The biopsy image given shows small, distinctive, glandlike structures filled with an acidophilic material similar to immature follicles known as Call-Exner bodies. The presence of such findings is diagnostic of granulosa cell tumors.

Granulosa cell tumors are ovarian sex-cord stromal tumors made up of cells that resemble the granulosa cells of the ovarian follicle. The most common driver mutations found are in the FOXL2 gene, which encodes a transcription factor important for granulosa cell development.

It most commonly presents in adult women aged over 55years (postmenopausal women) and occurs less commonly in pre-pubertal girls. The clinical presentation varies as follows:

  • In prepubertal girls estrogen secreted from the granulosa cell tumor results in pseudo-precocious puberty. There is hypertrophy of the breasts and myohyperplasia of the uterus.
  • In adult women, they may be associated with proliferative breast disease, postmenopausal irregular bleeding, breast tenderness, endometrial hyperplasia, and endometrial carcinoma. Abdominal pain and distension can occur due to enlarging tumor.
  • Occasionally, granulosa cell tumors produce androgens, masculinizing the patient

Gross examination: These are usually unilateral tumors. The cut section is soft and has a yellowish appearance due to intracellular lipids.

Microscopic examination: Call- Exner bodies which are small, distinctive, glandlike structures filled with an acidophilic material similar to immature follicles are diagnostic. Granulosa cells with pale, grooved, “coffee bean” nuclei are seen. These are small, cuboidal to polygonal cells that grow in anastomosing cords, sheets, or strands. Occasionally a thecoma component may be present as clusters or sheets of cuboidal to polygonal cells.

Detection and measurement of inhibin B are useful in diagnosing granulosa cell tumors and behave as a tumor marker. Measurement of inhibin B is more accurate than inhibin A.

Given below is a histopathological image depicting the Call-Exner bodies:

Related Pearl: WHO Classification of Ovarian Tumors

I.  Epithelial tumors (most common)

  • Serous tumors
  • Mucinous tumors
  • Endometrioid tumors
  • Clear cell 
  • Brenner tumors (transitional cell tumors)
  • Seromucinous
  • Undifferentiated carcinoma
II. Sex cord-stromal tumors:
  • Pure stromal cell tumors- Fibroma, Thecoma, Leydig cell tumor, Steroid cell tumor
  • Pure sex cord tumors- Granulosa cell tumor (Adult/Juvenile), Sertoli cell tumor
  • Mixed sex cord-stromal tumors- Sertoli–Leydig cell tumors

III. Germ cell tumors:

  • Dysgerminoma
  • Endodermal sinus tumor (Yolk sac tumor)
  • Embryonal carcinoma
  • Polyembryoma
  • Non-gestational choriocarcinoma
  • Teratoma (Mature/immature)
  • Mixed forms

IV. Gonadoblastoma

  • Pure
  • Mixed with dysgerminoma or other germ cell tumors

V. Soft tissue tumors not specific to ovary
VI. Miscellaneous tumors
VII. Secondary (metastatic) tumors
VIII. Tumor-like conditions

 

Related Pearl: Markers of Ovarian Neoplasm

Ovarian tumor Tumor marker Pathognomonic finding

Epithelial ovarian tumors

 CA-125,  CA-19-9, CEA Psammoma bodies (Serous epithelial tumor)
Endodermal sinus tumor AFP Schiller-Duval bodies
Dysgerminoma LDH, PLAP Lymphocytic infiltration
Embryonal carcinoma AFP, HCG -
Mature teratoma AFP Rokitansky protruberance
Granulosa cell tumor Inhibin Call–Exner bodies
Hilus cell tumor - Reinke's crystal
Brenner tumor - Walthard cell nest
Krukenberg tumor - Signet-ring cell
Clear cell tumor - Hobnail cell

Dysgerminoma (Mnemonic: DPL= Delhi Premier League)

  • D: Dysgerminoma
  • P: PLAP (placental alkaline phosphatase)
  • L: LDH (lactate dehydrogenase)

questions.text:
A 10-year-old girl presents with an ovarian mass. Her serum biomarkers are normal except for elevated AFP. Identify the most likely diagnosis.

AFP: Alpha-fetoprotein
questions.solution:
The above given findings are suggestive of endodermal sinus tumor. Alpha- fetoprotein is commonly produced by these tumors. It is also called yolk sac tumour. 

It is an aggressive malignant germ cell tumor of ovaries. It occurs in ovaries or testes and sacrococcygeal area in young children.  

On appearance these tumors are yellow, friable (hemorrhagic), solid mass.  

50% of the tumors have Schiller-Duval bodies. This structure consists of a central capillary surrounded by tumor cells, present within a cystic space that may be lined by flat to cuboidal tumor cells. They are pathognomonic when present.

questions.text: A 20-year-old nulligravida presented with right flank pain. MRI evaluation revealed a solid, enhancing  5×13×7 cm right ovarian mass. Salpingo-oophorectomy was successfully done and microscopic examination of the tumor cells showed a close resemblance to primordial germ cells. It was also noticed that the tumor appeared histologically identical to a testicular seminoma. Which of the following is not secreted by this tumor?
questions.solution:
An ovarian tumor in a young woman which consists of primordial germ cells and is histologically similar to seminoma suggests a diagnosis of an ovarian dysgerminoma. It does not secrete sex hormones.

Dysgerminoma usually arises in young women or in children, with an average incidence at the age of 20. It is the most common malignant germ cell tumour diagnosed during pregnancy.

The tumor is neutral and does not secrete either male or female sex hormones. It secretes placental alkaline phosphatase (ALP), lactate dehydrogenase (LDH) and β-hCG. Serum LDH and the isoenzymes LDH-1 and LDH-2 may be used in monitoring individuals or disease recurrence.

Dysgerminomas are primitive neoplasms that do not have the potential for further differentiation. They are the only germ cell malignancy with a significant rate of bilateral ovarian involvement (15-20%).

Microscopically, there is a monotonous proliferation of large, rounded, polyhedral clear cells that are rich in cytoplasmic glycogen and contain uniform central nuclei with one or a few prominent nucleoli. The tumor cells are histologically identical to the seminoma of the testis. The counterpart of seminoma in females is dysgerminoma. 

Treatment involves fertility-sparing surgery with unilateral salpingo-oophorectomy. It is highly radiosensitive and has a good prognosis.

The image below shows the histopathology of a dygerminoma, characterized by uniform cells resembling primordial germ cells separated by fibrous septa with lymphocytes. 

Related Pearl: Markers of Ovarian Neoplasm

Granulosa cell tumor Inhibin Call–Exner bodies
Hilus cell tumor - Reinke's crystal
Brenner tumor - Walthard cell nest
Krukenberg tumor - Signet-ring cell
Clear cell tumor - Hobnail cell

Dysgerminoma (Mnemonic: DPL= Delhi Premier League)

  • D: Dysgerminoma
  • P: PLAP (placental alkaline phosphatase)
  • L: LDH (lactate dehydrogenase)

questions.text: The most common ovarian tumor in women less than 20 years of age is _____.
questions.solution:
Germ cell tumors are the most common ovarian tumor in women aged less than 20 years.

Epithelial tumours are the commonest tumours. It accounts for 80% of all ovarian malignant tumours.

questions.text: A histopathological study of a patient with a suspected ovarian mass is given below. Based on the findings, identify the incorrect statement about this tumour and its management.

choices.text: Alpha-fetoprotein is used for post-treatment surveillance
Common in the premenarchal age group
Only stage III and IV tumours require chemotherapy

questions.solution:
Histopathological study shows the characteristic Schiller Duval body consistent with a diagnosis of yolk sac tumour (endodermal sinus tumour). Here, Option C is a false statement because all the patients having this tumour are treated with chemotherapy irrespective of stage as it is highly malignant.

Yolk sac tumours:

  • Account for about 10 to 20 percent of all malignant ovarian germ cell tumours
  • A third of all patients are pre-pubertal at the time of diagnosis. It is usually unilateral and highly malignant. (Option C)
  • The most common presentation is abdominal pain. The pain may be severe and be misdiagnosed as appendicitis
  • These tumors are usually associated with raised levels of AFP and alpha-1 antitrypsin
  • Grossly, these tumours are yellow, friable, solid masses
  • Histological features reveal cystic spaces lined by flattened epithelium. Vascular tufts are seen within the space - Schiller Duval body.
  • All patients are treated with chemotherapy irrespective of stage because it is highly malignant (Option D)
  • Alpha-fetoprotein is commonly produced and it is used for post-treatment surveillance. (Option A)

questions.text: What is the most common mode of spread in ovarian malignancies?
questions.solution:
The transcoelomic route is the most common and the earliest mode of spread in ovarian malignancies.

By this route, tumor cells spilled into the peritoneal cavity follow the path of the peritoneal fluid during respiration and get deposited in areas such as the paracolic gutter, cul-de-sac (pouch of Douglas), hemidiaphragm, mesenteries of the intestine, and the liver capsule.

Lymphatics is the next common mode of spread, especially in the advanced stages of the disease. The common sites involved are the para-aortic and pelvic nodes.

Hematogenous spread is uncommon and can seed a nidus in the parenchyma of organs such as the lung and the liver. Right pleural effusion is a common finding. This mode of spread mostly occur in survivors of the malignancy.

Transcoelomic spread > lymphatic spread > hematogenous spread

questions.text: A young lady presents with lower abdominal pain, abdominal fullness, and bloating sensation. On examination,  a large mass is palpable in the lower abdomen. Ultrasound shows a unilocular ovarian cyst of 7 cm with a solid component and 2 papillary projections. Which of the following is true regarding the reporting of her ultrasound?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of an ovarian cyst with ultrasound showing 7 cm cyst with a solid component and 2 papillary projections can be classified as O-RAD 4 according to the Ovarian-Adnexal Reporting and Data System (O-RADS).

O-RAD score is used to standardize the description of ovarian and adnexal pathology and helps in having a uniform terminology for describing the imaging characteristics of ovarian masses. It is used as a risk stratification classification for follow-up and management in clinical settings and also to determine the malignancy risk.

Ovarian-Adnexal Reporting and Data System (O-RADS)

SCORES RISK CATEGORY DESCRIPTION
0 Incomplete evaluation Lesion features relevant to risk stratification cannot be accurately characterized due to technical factors.
1 Normal Ovary Physiologic category: Size <3 cms - Ovarian follicle, corpus luteum.
2 Almost certainly benign (<1% risk of malignancy) Cysts >3 cm and <10 cm - Dermoid cyst, hemorrhagic cyst, endometrioma, etc.
3 Low risk of malignancy (1% to <10%)
  • Unilocular cyst >10 cm.
  • Multilocular cyst <10 cm smooth inner wall with colour score 1-3
4  Intermediate risk of malignancy (10% to <50%)
  • Unilocular cyst with solid components, and papillary projections(1-3).
  • Multilocular cyst with solid component, any size, colour score 1-2
5 High risk of malignancy (≥50%)
  • Unilocular cyst, ≥4 papillary projections
  • Bi/multilocular cyst with a solid component, colour score 3 to 4
  • Presence of ascites, peritoneal nodularity

questions.text: A patient comes with pain in her right lower quadrant for the last 2 weeks. On ultrasound, ovarian multiple thin echogenic bands are seen with no vascularity on doppler. Which of the following is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
An ovarian mass consisting of with USG findings of multiple thin echogenic bands with no vascularity on doppler is suggestive of a mature teratoma. 

The thin echogenic bands are seen due to the hair present in the teratoma while the lack of vascularity indicates a benign lesion. Other findings seen on USG include echogenic foci due to the sebaceous material and spotty calcifications due to teeth and bones. 

Teratomas are germ cell tumors. They contain embryonic tissues leading to the differentiation of cells along these pathways. Mature cystic teratoma, also known as dermoid cysts are unilocular in structure and have a smooth surface. They usually are lined by squamous epithelium with hair follicles leading to the formation of sebaceous material and hair. Other structures like teeth, bone, cartilage, thyroid tissue, and mucous membranes can also be found. 

Patients may have symptoms because of the mass size of the teratoma. In other patients, ovarian teratomas can result in torsion of the ovary. Other rare complications include rupture of the cyst and spillage of contents into the abdominal cavity. Treatment of mature teratomas involves excision in order to prevent complications. Otherwise, mature teratomas are generally innocent. 

Related Pearl: WHO Classification of Ovarian Tumors

II. Sex cord-stromal tumors:

V. Soft tissue tumors not specific to ovary
VI. Miscellaneous tumors
VII. Secondary (metastatic) tumors
VIII. Tumor-like conditions

questions.text: A lady in her late 40s came to the hospital with chief complaints of discomfort in the pelvic area, abdominal bloating, and quickly feeling full when eating. She also had a history of weight loss,  changes in bowel habits such as constipation, and a frequent need to urinate. An abnormality associated with the BRCA gene is suspected. Identify the false statement about the BRCA genes related to the underlying condition.

choices.text: BRCA 2 is more carcinogenic than BRCA 1
BRCA 1 is associated with hereditary breast ovarian cancer syndrome

questions.solution:
Option A is a false statement because BRCA 1 is more carcinogenic than BRCA 2, not vice-versa.

The underlying condition based on the given non-specific clinical features is ovarian carcinoma which is considerably more common and tends to develop at an earlier age in women with a germline BRCA1 pathogenic variant as compared to women with a germline BRCA2 pathogenic variant. 

  • 5–10% of malignant ovarian tumours are genetic.
  • BRCA 1 gene is on chromosome 17q.
  • BRCA 2 gene is on chromosome 13q.
  • BRCA 1 is associated with hereditary breast ovarian cancer syndrome.

Related Pearl: Comparison between BRCA 1 and BRCA 2:

Both BRCA1 and BRCA2 are tumor suppressor genes.

Carcinoma breast occurs at an earlier age and is bilateral and multicentric in inherited forms compared to sporadic cases.

  BRCA 1 BRCA 2
Location Long arm of chromosome 17  Long arm of chromosome 13
Differentiation Poorly differentiated Well-differentiated
Hormone receptor status ER/PR- Negative, Her-2 negative – triple negative ER/PR- Positive
Associated Cancers Breast, ovarian, colon, and prostate (lesser extent), Pancreas (lesser extent)  cancers Breast, ovarian, colon, prostate, pancreas, gall bladder, stomach cancers, and melanoma
Male breast carcinoma Low risk Increased risk
Fanconi’s anemia Not associated Associated
Medullary carcinoma Associated Not associated

questions.text: A 49-year-old woman presented with dull pain over the right lower abdomen. CT scan revealed a multiloculated adnexal mass. Exploratory laparotomy showed the following mass, which on microscopy showed multiloculated cysts lined by a single layer of mucin-containing epithelium. CA-125 levels were not elevated. Which of the following is incorrect regarding the condition?
questions.solution:
The above clinical scenario, gross image, and microscopy findings are suggestive of mucinous cystadenoma. Serous cystadenocarcinomas are the most common epithelial ovarian cancer (option B is incorrect). 

Mucinous cystadenomas are mostly benign. They are usually present during the third to sixth decade of life and the majority of them are unilateral.

They are usually multilocular, thick-walled, and have a smooth surface. Histology shows multiple cysts and glands liner by simple non-stratified mucinous epithelium. The epithelium may resemble gastric foveolar type or intestinal epithelium containing goblet cells. 

Complications of mucinous cystadenoma of the ovary include torsion, spontaneous rupture, pseudomyxoma peritonei, and secondary malignancies. Secondary malignancy occurs in 5-10% of mucinous cystadenomas. 

In pseudomyxoma peritonei, the peritoneal cavity is filled with coagulated mucinous martial adherent to the omentum and intestines. During laparotomy, the lesions resemble boiled sago pudding. It is frequently associated with mucinous cystadenoma of the ovary but are also seen with mucocele of the appendix and carcinoma of the large intestine in men. 

Cystectomy is the adequate treatment for ovarian cystadenoma but recurrence may be seen in patients treated with cystectomy.

Note- Serous cystadenocarcinomas account for 40-50% of malignant epithelial ovarian tumors. Microscopically, tumor cells show severe nuclear atypia and anaplasia. Malignant ovarian tumors are associated with elevated CA-125 levels.

questions.text: Which of the following is incorrectly paired?

choices.text: Brenner tumors - Sex cord stromal tumor
Sertoli cell tumor - Sex cord stromal tumor

questions.solution:
Brenner tumor/ transitional cell tumor is an epithelial tumor not a sex cord-stromal tumor

Brenner tumors are uncommon tumors of the ovary. They are typically small to moderate-sized tumors and are mostly benign. However, rarely, if tumors are seen with benign Brenner nests admixed with malignant tumor cells, they are known as malignant Brenner tumors. If it has greater than 50% malignant transitional type epithelium, then it is known as transitional cell carcinomas of the ovary.

Clinically, they may present with vague abdominopelvic pain in postmenopausal women and are mostly detected incidentally as in this patient. Histopathologically, they are characterized by fibrous tissue with interspersed nests of transitional epithelium. These cells may have nuclei with a characteristic longitudinal groove.

questions.text: A 26-year-old female patient presented with mild pain in the lower abdomen. She has had 2 full-term normal deliveries earlier. Her last menstrual period was 3 weeks back. On pelvic examination, you find a palpable mass in the adnexa. On the USG pelvis, you find a 6 cm ovarian cyst, which is clear and unilocular. What should be your next best step?
questions.solution:
A clear ovarian cyst detected at 3 weeks after the last menstrual period, with minimal symptoms and a size of 6 cm, in a woman of reproductive age group is most likely to be a functional ovarian cyst. The next best step in the management of this case is to observe and follow up for the cyst after 2–3 months.

Functional cysts may be follicular cysts, lutein cysts, multiple functional cysts, or corpus luteal cysts. The size of the cysts should be at least 3 cm but not more than 7 cm.

  • Follicular cysts: They can be single or multiple. They may vary in size but generally do not exceed 5.0 cm in diameter. They form as a result of the failure of absorption of the fluid in an incompletely developed follicle or anovulation. They are usually asymptomatic unless there is a hemorrhage in the cyst. Most follicular cysts disappear spontaneously within 4-8 weeks.

  • There are 2 types of Lutein cysts:

    • Corpus luteum/ Granulosa lutein cysts: They are functional and non-neoplastic. Persistent corpus luteum cysts may cause local pain, tenderness, or delayed menstruation. These cysts are often palpable clinically.
    • Theca lutein cysts: These cysts can sometimes enlarge to several centimeters in diameter. They are usually bilateral and filled with straw-colored fluid.

Treatment:

A simple unilocular cyst less than 7 cm in the reproductive age group is often a functional cyst. It should be observed. Most functional cysts resolve spontaneously over 4-6 months. A repeat ultrasound is needed to check for a resolution. Oral combined pills may be prescribed for 3-4 months in women of reproductive age as this may help in its resolution.

A benign ovarian tumor of more than 7 cm requires removal. Open laparotomy is preferred to laparoscopic excision.

A simple unilocular cyst measuring less than 5 cm in a postmenopausal woman - It can be observed with repeated ultrasound and CA-125 every 3 months. A persistent cyst requires removal via laparoscopy or laparotomy.

questions.text: Which of the following is a glomerulus-like structure composed of a central blood vessel enveloped by tumor cells within a space that is also lined by tumor cells?
questions.solution:
The Schiller-Duval body is a glomerulus-like structure composed of a central blood vessel enveloped by tumor cells within a space that is also lined by tumor cells.

The image below shows Schiller-Duval body, which is pathognomic of endodermal sinus tumor. 

Other options:-

Option A: Call-Exner bodies are small, distinctive, gland-like structures filled with an acidophilic material similar to immature follicles. 

The images below show Call-Exner bodies, which are pathognomic of granulosa cell tumours. Granulosa cells with pale, grooved, “coffee bean” nuclei are seen.

Option C: Walthard cell rests are benign clusters of epithelial cells resembling transitional cells. 

The image below shows Walthard cell rests and coffee bean nuclei, which are pathognomic of Brenner's tumour.

Option D: Hobnail cells are clear cells showing large dark nuclei protruding into the lumen. 

The image below shows the hobnail cell, which is the pathognomic of a clear-cell ovarian tumour. 

Related Pearl: Markers of Ovarian Neoplasm

Endodermal sinus tumor AFP Schiller-Duval bodies
Dysgerminoma LDH, PLAP Lymphocytic infiltration

Mature teratoma AFP Rokitansky protruberance
Granulosa cell tumor Inhibin Call–Exner bodies

Brenner tumor - Walthard cell nest

Dysgerminoma (Mnemonic: DPL= Delhi Premier League)

  • D: Dysgerminoma
  • P: PLAP (placental alkaline phosphatase)
  • L: LDH (lactate dehydrogenase)

Related Pearl: WHO Classification of Ovarian Tumors

I.  Epithelial tumors (most common)

  • Serous tumors
  • Mucinous tumors
  • Endometrioid tumors
  • Clear cell 
  • Brenner tumors (transitional cell tumors)
  • Seromucinous
  • Undifferentiated carcinoma
II. Sex cord-stromal tumors:
  • Pure stromal cell tumors- Fibroma, Thecoma, Leydig cell tumor, Steroid cell tumor
  • Pure sex cord tumors- Granulosa cell tumor (Adult/Juvenile), Sertoli cell tumor
  • Mixed sex cord-stromal tumors- Sertoli–Leydig cell tumors

III. Germ cell tumors:

  • Dysgerminoma
  • Endodermal sinus tumor (Yolk sac tumor)
  • Embryonal carcinoma
  • Polyembryoma
  • Non-gestational choriocarcinoma
  • Teratoma (Mature/immature)
  • Mixed forms

IV. Gonadoblastoma

  • Pure
  • Mixed with dysgerminoma or other germ cell tumors

V. Soft tissue tumors not specific to ovary
VI. Miscellaneous tumors
VII. Secondary (metastatic) tumors
VIII. Tumor-like conditions

questions.text: A 56-year-old patient presents with bleeding per vaginum. She has had intermittent spotting for the last 3 months. Menopause occurred 8 years ago.  Serum estradiol levels are elevated. Which of the following options can be likely etiologies of her symptoms?
questions.solution:
This patient is presenting with postmenopausal bleeding. The presence of an elevated estradiol level makes an ovarian malignancy likely. Ovarian thecoma and granulosa cell tumors are associated with increased estrogen production and are likely to cause this patient's symptoms. 

Granulosa cell tumors are low-grade malignant tumors that have cells similar to the cells of the Graafian follicle and theca interna cells. Thecoma is a benign tumor of the theca cells. Both these cells produce estrogen due to them arising from cells that are responsible for estrogen production in the body. The estrogen causes unopposed growth of the endometrium and leads to breakthrough bleeding which can cause postmenopausal bleeding. 

Vaginal bleeding occurring after 6 months of amenorrhoea in women of menopausal age group should be considered as postmenopausal bleeding and investigated. This must be done irrespective of a previous diagnosis of menopause.

All postmenopausal women with unexpected uterine bleeding should be evaluated for endometrial carcinoma. Even in those women who are perimenopausal, endometrial carcinoma must be suspected if they fall under the above-mentioned clinical category.

An abdominal ultrasound should be done to evaluate for causes of post-menopausal bleeding. 

Other Options:

Fibromas are usually non-functional and do not produce hormones

Teratomas contain all three types of cells of embryonic origin, and in some cases the differentiated thyroid tissue can be functional and produces thyroid hormone. This is known as struma ovarii. They do not produce estrogen.

questions.text: Histopathological examination of a specimen received after staging laparotomy for an ovarian mass revealed the following. Which of the following tumor is associated with this finding?
questions.solution:
The given histological finding denotes Psammoma bodies which are histopathological findings of ovarian papillary serous cystadenoma and cystadenocarcinoma.

They are concentrically calcified basophilic structures seen in areas of cellular degeneration. Its presence per se does not denote malignancy.

Psammoma bodies are commonly seen in certain tumors such as:

  • Papillary thyroid carcinoma
  • Papillary renal cell carcinoma
  • Ovarian tumors: Papillary serous cystadenoma and cystadenocarcinoma
  • Meningiomas, in the central nervous system
  • Peritoneal and Pleural Mesothelioma
  • Prolactinoma of the pituitary
  • Lung Adenocarcinoma

questions.text: A 26-year-old nulliparous woman is diagnosed with early-stage ovarian cancer. Which surgery should be done in her case?
questions.solution:
Unilateral oophorectomy is preferred in a young woman who has not completed her family in case of early-stage disease.

Related Pearl: Management in Ovarian Malignancy

questions.text: A 63-year-old woman presented with complaints of pelvic and abdominal pain, and significant weight loss. A CT scan of the pelvis showed bilateral ovarian tumors and a CT scan of the chest showed pleural effusion. Pleural fluid analysis showed positive cytology for ovarian tumor cells. What FIGO stage does this belong to?
questions.solution:
According to the FIGO staging of carcinoma of the ovary, fallopian tube, and primary peritoneal carcinoma, the presence of pleural effusion with positive cytology is classified as stage IV-A.

Other options:

Option A: Stage III-A1 is defined as a tumor involving one or both ovaries with positive retroperitoneal lymph nodes only.

Option B: Stage III-B is defined as a tumor involving one or both ovaries with macroscopic, extrapelvic, and peritoneal metastasis ≤2cm ± positive retroperitoneal nodes with extension to the capsule of the liver or spleen.

Option D: Stage IV-B is defined as hepatic and/or splenic parenchymal metastasis, metastasis to extra-abdominal organs including inguinal lymph nodes and lymph nodes outside of the abdominal cavity.

Related Pearl: Staging of Ovarian cancer

  • Stage I:
    • A: Tumor confined to unilateral ovary
    • B: Bilateral ovary
    • C: Capsule rupture
      • C1: Surgical  spill
      • C2: pre-operative capsule rupture
      • C3: malignant ascites
  • Stage II:
    • A: Extension to fallopian tubes/ uterus.
    • B: Extension to other pelvic intraperitoneal tissues
  • Stage III:
    • A1:Positive retroperitoneal lymph nodes(para-aortic)
    • A2:microscopic extrapelvic peritoneal deposits
    • B: Macroscopic peritoneal deposits <2cm ± positive retroperitoneal lymph nodes. Includes extension to capsule of liver/spleen.  
    • C: Macroscopic peritoneal deposits >2cm ± positive retroperitoneal lymph nodes. Includes extension to capsule of liver/spleen.
  • Stage 4:
    • A: Malignant pleural effusion
    • B: Extra-abdominal spread/Inguinal lymph node involvement

questions.text: A young girl presents with gradually progressive abdominal distension, cough, breathlessness, and pleural effusion on the right side. USG showed an edematous right ovary with a large cyst and disruption in adnexal flow on Doppler. The mass is removed and its contents are shown below. What is the likely cause of her ascites and pleural effusion?
questions.solution:
An ovarian mass consisting of hair, bone, and sebaceous material is suggestive of teratoma. The triad of teratoma with ascites and pleural effusion points towards the likely diagnosis of pseudo-Meigs syndrome.

Pseudo-Meigs syndrome presents with ascites and pleural effusion in association with benign ovarian tumors (other than ovarian fibromas) such as teratoma, struma ovarii, mucinous cystadenoma, etc. Other causes include fibroids/leiomyoma, and secondary metastatic tumors to the ovary.

The pleural effusions are usually right-sided, even though the left-sided and bilateral effusions are possible. Resolution of ascites and pleural effusion is seen after the removal of the tumor. 

Teratomas are germ cell tumors. They contain embryonic tissues leading to the differentiation of cells along these pathways. Mature cystic teratoma, also known as dermoid cysts are unilocular in structure and have a smooth surface. They usually are lined by squamous epithelium with hair follicles leading to the formation of sebaceous material and hair. Other structures like teeth, bone, cartilage, thyroid tissue, and mucous membranes can also be found. 

Patients may have symptoms because of the mass size of the teratoma. In other patients, ovarian teratomas can result in torsion of the ovary. Other rare complications include rupture of the cyst and spillage of contents into the abdominal cavity. Treatment of mature teratomas involves excision to prevent complications. Otherwise, mature teratomas are generally innocent.

Other options:

Option A: Meigs syndrome is also characterized by a triad of ovarian tumors, ascites, and pleural effusion. Ovarian fibroma was originally described in the triad of True Meigs syndrome. The other causes include granulosa cell tumor, Brenner tumor, or thecoma.

Option C: Pseudo-pseudo Meigs syndrome is a manifestation of SLE (systemic lupus erythematosus) defined by ascites, pleural effusion, and elevated CA-125 levels.

Option D: Fitz-Hugh-Curtis syndrome occurs as a complication of pelvic inflammatory disease caused by Chlamydia trachomatis or Neisseria gonorrhea. It is characterized by the inflammation of the peritoneum and the tissues surrounding the liver (perihepatitis). Symptoms include sudden onset of severe pain in the right upper quadrant of the abdomen, fever, chills, and malaise.

questions.text: A woman presenting with deepening of the voice, coarse hair on the upper lip, bitemporal hair thinning was found to have a unilateral pelvic mass. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The clinical picture of hirsutism (coarse hair over upper lip), male pattern baldness (bitemporal hair thinning) and deepening of voice along with a unilateral pelvic mass in a reproductive aged female is suggestive of a virilizing tumour of the ovary. Arrhenoblastoma or Sertoli-Leydig cell tumour of the ovary is a virilizing tumour of the ovary. 

Sertoli-Leydig cell tumours are a type of sex-cord stromal ovarian tumor. It is most commonly seen in women of reproductive age group. These produce excess androgens and are hence known as virilizing tumours. Menstrual irregularities and signs of virilization like hirsutism and deepening of the voice are common presenting complaints. Microscopy reveals Sertoli cells and Leydig cells. Treatment is surgical excision. 

Other options:

Option A: Granulosa cell tumours arise from granulosa cells which form part of the developing ovarian follicle. They are unilateral and the mass is cystic and encapsulated. They usually secrete estrogen.

Option C: Endodermal sinus tumor or yolk sac tumor is a type of germ cell tumor that is most common in children. Schiller Duval bodies are seen in yolk sac tumors and resemble endodermal sinuses. Patients with yolk sac tumors have signs and symptoms depending on the location of cancer (sudden abdominal distension, pain etc).

Option D: Choriocarcinoma is a malignant gestational trophoblastic neoplasia typically seen following a molar pregnancy. However, choriocarcinomas secrete elevated amounts of beta hCG and would present with symptoms such as abnormal uterine bleeding or hyperthyroidism. 

Related Pearl: WHO Classification of Ovarian Tumors

  • Mucinous tumors

III. Germ cell tumors:

questions.text: A 50-year-old female patient has been diagnosed with an ovarian tumor. Histopathological examination of tumor specimen reveals sheets of mucin-producing signet ring cells as seen below.  Identify the true statement regarding this ovarian tumor.

choices.text: Normal shape of ovary is retained
Ovary is attached to nearby viscera and becomes immobile

questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario with histopathology showing signet ring cells is suggestive of Krukenberg tumor and in this ovarian tumor, the normal shape of the ovary is retained.

Krukenberg tumor: These are secondary growth in the ovary and most often arise from a primary carcinoma of the stomach (70%), large bowel (15%), and breast (6%).

Features:

  • Usually bilateral (Option D)
  • Have a smooth surface
  • They retain the shape of the normal ovary.
  • There is no tendency to form adhesions with neighboring viscera and they are freely movable in the pelvis. (Option C)
  • There is no infiltration through the capsule (Option A)
  • Have a waxy consistency

Histologically, Numerous signet-ring cells with pale cytoplasm are seen.
